content: The "Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Act of 1997" establishes a Commission to examine land claims and includes provisions for a Community Land Grant Study Center. It also outlines definitions, findings, powers of the Commission, reporting requirements, termination, and authorization of appropriations. The "Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Act of 1997" defines key terms such as Commission, Treaty of Guadalupe-Hidalgo, and eligible descendant. It specifies criteria for eligible descendants related to Mexican citizenship, community land grants, and becoming a US citizen within ten years of the treaty. The "Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Act of 1997" defines terms like community land grant as a village or town with land held in common by ten or more families under a grant from Spain or Mexico before specific dates. "Reconstituted" refers to restoring a valid community land grant to full municipality status. Congress recognizes New Mexico's unique history with Spanish and Mexican land grants, which have not been fully implemented according to the Treaty of Guadalupe-Hidalgo. This has raised questions about land ownership in the state. Certain public lands in the State of New Mexico still exist, and Congress has used land claim commissions in the past to examine disputed land possession questions successfully. The Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Commission is established with three members appointed by the President. Members serve for the life of the Commission and receive compensation at the level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission is tasked with examining land claims. The Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Commission, established with three members appointed by the President, is responsible for examining land claims. Any 10 eligible descendants of a community land grant can file a petition seeking validation of the land claim, which must be submitted within four years of the enactment of the Act and include names, addresses, and proof of the land being a community grant at the time of the Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty. The Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Commission requires petitioners to provide details of the community land grant, their residency or intention to settle on the land, and all known facts and documents related to the grant. The Commission holds hearings where interested parties can participate, and it has the power to issue subpoenas for witness testimony. The Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Commission can issue subpoenas to compel witnesses to testify and produce evidence related to petitions. Failure to comply with a subpoena may result in a court order for testimony or evidence. The Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Commission can issue subpoenas for witnesses and serve court process within the judicial district where the person resides or can be found. The Commission will make a decision on the validity of the community land grant based on the facts presented in a petition and a hearing. The Commission will make a decision on the validity of the community land grant described in the petition, including a recommendation on whether it should be reconstituted and its lands restored. The Commission will establish a Community Land Grant Study Center at the Onate Center in Alcalde, New Mexico to assist in its activities. Additionally, the Commission will have miscellaneous powers. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, administer oaths, and accept gifts or property to aid its work. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. Gifts or proceeds received are deposited in the Treasury for disbursement as ordered by the Commission. The Commission has the authority to accept gifts or property to aid its work, with disbursement as ordered by the Commission. It can use the United States mails and receive administrative support services upon request. The Commission is considered an agency of the United States for immunity purposes. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress after making decisions, including recommendations on community land grants. The Commission will terminate 180 days after submitting the final report. $1,000,000 is authorized for the Commission's activities and the Community Land Grant Study Center.
